texts.shortText: Well-known and extremely common species that builds large boulder-like reefs of coarse sandy tubes, each tube with a flared opening. Especially common in intertidal sites on the west coast, where the reefs form dominant features on the shore. The head bears a crown of short, dark-blue, un-branched feeding tentacles and a conspicuous double row of stiff, flat golden setae that are used to close off the entrance to the tube. The back half of the body is extremely thin and folded back under the anterior section, so that feces can be voided from the entrance to the tube!
Body typically about 90 mm, and reach 110 mm; reefs can be 1 m or more across.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: Central Namibia to southern KwaZulu-Natal (but recent genetic work shows specimens from the east coast probably need to be described as another new species).

Use sand particles collected from the water column and mucus to construct large reefs of strong, sandy tubes. Each tube is blind-ended and has a flanged opening that concentrates food at the entrance. The reefs form important habitats that are colonised by a wide variety of other species. Predated upon by the Pustular triton Argobuccinum pustulosum, which secretes an acid saliva to dissolve the protective crown of bristles. Sometimes also gathered by fishers as bait. Considering its importance surprisingly little research has been conducted on this species.
Suspension feeder, gathering fine organic materials from the water column.
Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.

Replaced by the similar Idanthyrsus pennatus in northern KwaZulu-Natal. The extensive sandy reefs and golden bristles on the heads are distinctive. Icecream-cone worms Amphictece capensis have similar bristles, but are solitary and live in perfectly conical tubes buried vertically in sand.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 72).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2 (p. 673).

Day, JA (1969). Feeding of the cymatiid gastropod, Argobuccinum argus, in relation to the structure of the proboscis and secretions of the proboscis gland. American Zoologist, 9(3), 909-916.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
